awd_titl_txt: Dampening autoimmunity with encapsulated autoantigens in polyphenolic capsules
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical: This award by the Biomaterials program in the Division of Materials Research to University of Alabama at Birmingham is to develop biologically-active biomaterials for potential treatment of an autoimmune disease, such as Type 1 diabetes (T1D). Restoring immune tolerance, i.e., the inability of the immune system to respond to specific autoantigens such as insulin is a major challenge in T1D. To address this challenge, this project will develop novel immunoprotective polymeric nano- and micro-particles with encased insulin to dampen aberrant Type 1 diabetes autoimmune responses. This research will impact the design and application of a new type of polymer material with autoimmune modulating activity and will provide a fundamental understanding of the physical and chemical properties of these materials at biological interfaces. The design of this material will open new prospects in various bio-related areas such as bioengineering and tissue engineering and autoimmune therapies.  The educational objective of this project is to develop a discovery-driven multidisciplinary biomaterials/polymer sciences program at University of Alabama at Birmingham in promoting diversity from the high school through graduate-level. These students, including underrepresented minorities, will be trained in modern aspects of biopolymer sciences including state-of-the-art synthetic and analytical methods, and they will take part in intensive multidisciplinary collaborations between the Departments of Chemistry and Microbiology. 

Technical: The goal of this proposal is to develop a new type of immunomodulatory particulate material with encased autoantigens (insulin) for dampening autoimmune responses in Type 1 diabetes (T1D), and to gain a fundamental understanding of the mechanism of immune modulating activity. These hollow particles will be designed through hydrogen-bonded assemblies of polyphenolic tannic acid (TA) with neutral polymers to produce micro- and nano-capsules for delivery of insulin to immune cells and restore their immune tolerance.  The objectives of the proposed study are as follows: 1) synthesis TA-based microcapsules with novel temperature-sensitive diblock copolymers, and explore their immune cell uptake properties; 2) explore the loading of insulin into capsules with tunable thermal, antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties; 3) investigate immunomodulation of antigen-presenting cells with TA-based capsules with dampening autoimmune responses in an autoantigen-specific manner; and 4) study the interaction of these materials with antigen-presenting cells in vitro.  Correlations between material physical/chemical properties and function of immune cells is pivotal for transformative knowledge in developing immunomodulatory materials for treating a broad spectrum of autoimmune diseases.  Access to state-of-the-art techniques with unique capabilities of in situ nano-scaled measurements, advanced imaging, and immunology facilities will ensure the successful completion of the project. Recruitment and/or mentoring of students at different levels - High school, undergraduate, and graduate including underrepresented minorities - and training them in modern aspects of biopolymer sciences including state-of-the-art synthetic and analytical methods are parts of this award.

por.por_cntn:
Most autoimmune disorders are mediated by immune T cells, where the activation of autoreactive T cells leads to the breakdown of immunological self-tolerance. Restoring immune tolerance, i.e., the inability of the immune system to respond to specific autoantigens is a significant challenge in autoimmune therapies.  Current approaches use non-specific immunomodulatory agents that suppress the immune system leading to severe infections and malignancies. The goal of our grant was to develop a new type of immunomodulatory particulate material for dampening Type 1 Diabetes autoimmune responses, including gaining a fundamental understanding of the mechanism of their autoimmune modulating activity. 

Intellectual Merit

We synthesized  temperature-responsive diblock and triblock copolymers and developed their aqueous assemblies into polymeric vesicles/nanocapsules that showed excellent biocompatibility. We demonstrated the innovative aspects of these polymersomes, including the ease of therapeutics loading, including peptide-based and RNA-based therapeutics. We found that these nanovesicles can change their structural characteristics in the physiologically relevant temperature range and can be used for cell mimicry studies. We discovered that tannic acid (TA)-based microcapsules can provide ultrasound (US) imaging contrast that can be controlled through capsule shell thickness, polymer rigidity, and polymer molecular weight. We also demonstrated that these microcapsules could protect encapsulated therapeutics from degradation or clearance prior to reaching the target and have a native US contrast as a means of visualizing the drug carrier and a trigger for drug release. We also developed modifications of the polyphenolic capsules for visualization through MRI- and PET imaging techniques, the most clinically relevant visualization methods. We developed a synergistic manganoporphyrin-polyphenol polymeric nano-thin coating and hollow microcapsules with efficient antioxidant activity and controllable ROS modulation. We demonstrated that the TA-based capsules composed of the antioxidant and a neutral polymer with encapsulated antigens effectively blunt innate immune-derived proinflammatory third signal synthesis necessary for antigen-specific effector T cell responses and presented a prospective strategy for T cell-mediated autoimmunity. We discovered that this layer-by-layer antioxidant coating could reduce oxidative stress following allotransplantation of the TA-based capsule-encapsulated islets can elicit localized immunosuppression and potentially delay graft destruction in human islet transplantation. Gene expression analysis of TA-coating-encapsulated grafts post-transplantation displayed reduced proinflammatory cytokines and chemokines while enhancing alternatively activated macrophage Retnla, Arg1, and Stat6 mRNA accumulation.

Broader Impacts

This research provided fundamental knowledge on polyphenolic materials that have strong potential for the development of a safer alternative to immunosuppressive drugs, which treat autoimmune diseases and prevent the rejection of medical implants or transplanted organs by weakening the immune system. Encapsulating medications inside the developed materials can allow for dampening autoimmune processes without severely weakening the immune system. Our findings on temperature-responsive polymersomes can further the development of clinically relevant therapeutic carriers, expanding the next generation of advanced therapeutic vehicles with minimal side effects. Our approach to inhibit pro-inflammatory immune responses without systemic immunosuppression is significant for successful islet transplants in humans. 

The encapsulation, release, and imaging strategy provided by our antioxidant-based capsules can enable the use of MRI guidance for targeted drug delivery while potentially improving treatment efficacy.  The developed polymeric platforms have a substantial value in biomedical imaging, potentially leading to the advancement of human health through molecularly targeted, MRI-guided precision drug delivery.

From the educational perspective, the project helped to  expand a discovery-driven multidisciplinary biomaterials/polymer sciences program at the UAB.  The project supported one postdoctoral researcher and involved participation in this research of nine graduate students with five of them graduated with Ph.D. degrees in Polymer Chemistry, and three with Masters degree in Chemistry; 10 undergraduates with one of them as a paper co-author, and five continuing their graduate education at UAB (two) and at other USA universities. The students have been trained in synthetic aspects of biomaterials and polymer science, including advanced methods of controlled synthesis and materials characterization, and were involved in extensive collaborations through and beyond UAB. This project provided new interdisciplinary collaborative research between the UAB Departments of Chemistry, Microbiology (Immunology), Radiology, Cardiovascular Diseases, UAB Comprehensive Diabetes Center, and the Southern Research (Birmingham, AL), Oak Ridge National Laboratory (TN), and the University of Alberta (Canada). These collaborative efforts will continue to stimulate awareness to the needs of the UAB biomedical research community for specialized polymer-based biomaterials as novel platforms for antioxidant/immunotherapy.

The results generated by this project were disseminated through 13 peer-reviewed articles, two book chapters, three conference papers, and 41 presentations given at national and international scientific conferences.  This research led to two patent applications and was highlighted on two journal Covers of the peer-reviewed scientific journals, and was numerously featured in the UAB News and broader public media (Twitter, Mendeleev).  Besides education and research, the results of this project work will be beneficial to the USA (and beyond) people through the development of polymer materials for biomedical applications, including targeting cancers, and the development of artificial cells able to adapt to environmental impacts.
